utterances: …you know, we're here in New York and the New York Giants just won, and we're - yesterday, we just had Super Tuesday.
We had the Super Bowl parade for the New York Giants.
And we have fashion week going on.
We got a bunch of things going on in the city.
And yeah, I really do think that Super Tuesday in this race dominates the discussion that, you know, tables everywhere.
Well, one thing I thought that was something to note was that you finally saw the liberals actually vying for it - the black vote.
Right.
I always likened blacks who vote - and the liberal saw it as being somewhat like - being affiliated with a spouse that's abusive.
Right.
You know, no matter how abusive your spouse is, you're still going to go back to this person.
So in this case, this is going to be a big question mark whether or not we actually see black folk basically dividing their vote.
Definitely.
So you're saying that it's in play, but, Lauren, what about on the Republican side?
I mean, is the, you know, and we've talked a lot about whether or not Republicans have gone to African-American theme debates.
Do you see any indication that because of what's going on on the Democratic side, Republicans might start playing ball with the black vote?
One would think that I haven't really seen that much of an indication.
I do know that there's a large conservative coalitioning for Mike Huckabee.
I've seen a lot of interesting information about that.
But, you know, they didn't go to black debate and I still sort of feel like they're not investing a lot of energy into black vote.
I think right now they're concerned about their base.
I think the party's base is at odds right now.
I mean, you know, at that South Carolina debate, it really looked like the Democrats didn't have their start(ph) together.
It looked very fickle.
The Republicans were looking at the party to have their start(ph) together.
But now after Super Tuesday, they (unintelligible) three people in it.
With the Democrats, you only have to worry about the two, and we're still in primary vote.
I think when they nail down their candidate in the final, we go ahead.
And the Republicans will start pandering to the black vote.
Well, I think, with McCain, especially I'm looking at him as a liberal wolf in conservative sheep's clothing.
So I mean - so right now, if anything - you see that the public is actually going more to the centrist political paradigm.
So we'll see if it actually holds water as the race continues.
All right.
Well, guys, we're going to have to take a break but you will stay with us.
We've been talking with bloggers Lauren Williams, Desmond Burton and Jozen Cummings.
(Soundbite of music)
I'm Farai Chideya.
And this is NEWS & NOTES.
We continue our Bloggers' Roundtable with Lauren Williams, the editor of the blog Stereohyped; pop culture critic Desmond Burton of the blog Afronerd; and Jozen Cummings.
He writes the blog Broke Thoughts on KING magazine's Web site and is the site's editor.
So, Jozen, you are blogging about celebrity endorsements.
Specifically you're writing about this new video, which, again, I've got 10 million e-mails about -called ""Yes We Can"" featuring Will.I.Am and a lot of other celebs.
Let's take a listen.
(Soundbite of song, ""Yes We Can"")
Will.I.Am (Musician): (Singing) It was a creed written into the founding documents that declared the destiny of a nation.
Yes we can.
It was whispered by slaves and abolitionists as they blazed a trail toward freedom.
Yes we can.
Yes we can.
So if you've got your invincible goggles on, you can see a bunch of celebrities and - black and white - and you know, split screen with Barack Obama.
Do you think that this has juiced the campaign a little bit, Jozen?
I think it's - no, I don't really think…
(Soundbite of laughter)
I don't really think that it's juiced the campaign of any more than it's already been juiced.
Barack Obama since the beginning has - to me-been a popular celebrity candidate.
And this Will.I.Am track that just came out only added to that, but not in a way where we're going to see like a boost in popularity.
Of all the candidates outside and probably Hillary Clinton, I would say that Barack Obama is actually the biggest celebrity.

I mean he has serious star power, not just political power, star power, and that comes from the fact that he's been affiliated from - with celebrities since day one, since Oprah, JZ, Beyonce, Chris Rock.
They've all participated in this movement in some capacity or another.
I think, if anything, that just adds soundtrack to his campaign.
UNIDENTIFIED ACTOR #2: (As character) Dare to engage.
Now you've found the joystick.
Finally, what about this soybean purchase that the Chinese announced?
Now, Lauren and Desmond, I want to tick off a few other people now.
We've talked about Barack's supporters but Hillary Clinton has Barbara Streisand, former porn star Janet Jamison(ph), Jerry Springer, 50 Cent.
Huckabee has pro-wrestler Ric Flair, action-movie man Chuck Norris and the heavily-armed rocker Ted Nugent.
McCain has the Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling, California governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone, Tom Selleck.
Ron Paul has Howard Stern and Arlo Guthrie.
Like see them go on tour together.
Mitt Romney has Donny and Marie Osmond, Anne Coulter and Pat Boone.
Now, that's a pretty diverse basket.
Would any of those people sway your vote, Lauren?
Well, you know, Arlo Guthrie - he has, sort of, vote, you know, whoever endorses.
(Soundbite of laughter)
No, I don't think any of them would sway my vote.

I think that when you look at the celebrities that are endorsing each candidate, you kind of see that, you know, you kind of see in a wider sense these sorts of people that the candidates are, you know, are grabbing in terms of real voters, and, you know, the young voters love Barack Obama and I think that's apparent, and the fact that he has…
And don't forget that the grateful dad, the surviving members did come back for Barack as well so it's not just young people…
It's not just the young voters.
So, Desmond…
They want to smoke.
They want (unintelligible) clear.
Yeah.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Desmond, what do you - I mean, is this important?
Is this whole celeb…
Not at all.
Not at all.
Okay.
I think that the public presently is showing you that they really want to vote for who they really want to vote for.
And I think that if anything, we're looking at living mannequins when it comes to celebrities in solidification of society.
So I don't put any kind of, any real bearing with these individuals.
I want to take all of us into so much more serious waters, moving on to this story about 26-year-old Tarika Wilson of Lima, Ohio.
She was shot and killed during a drug raid last month.
Her 1-year-old son was wounded.

Now, the police chief says they'd long been investigating her boyfriend - the boyfriend was arrested later that night, charged with suspicion of possession of crack cocaine - and both marijuana and crack were found in the house.
So we spoke with the member of the Lima Police Department.
He confirmed these details.
The police officer in the shooting has been placed on administrative leave, and the police have released very little other information about whether Tarika Wilson was armed.
Lauren, you've been blogging about this.
What are people saying?
Shockingly, a lot of my readers, sort of, you know, they - the police brutality aspect of it.

You know, the shocking fact that a policeman shot this woman and her baby is sort of being glossed over, and people are really getting into a conversation about the choices that the woman made and how her life choices put her in this dangerous situation and whether or not, you know, not that she had it coming to her, but sort of just that if she hadn't been the girlfriend of this drug dealer, she never would have, you know, been killed by the cop (unintelligible).
I think that what we're seeing here is some Jena Six fatigue, though.
This is definitely a situation that I feel is worth speaking out about and definitely worthy of being upset about.

But, you know, the kinds of reactions that Lauren is getting on her blog, I think, a lot of that has to do with the fact that after Jena Six, we put so much into that as a community and as a people, that now we're just kind of exhausted, and the next thing that we come together for as a people, well, we're going to pick that thing very carefully.

And I don't necessarily agree with that mindset - and I can't speak for everybody - but I really do think that whenever we get into - whenever we get up and arms about racial injustice, it kind of makes it difficult for us to do it again the next day and the next day after that.
What about that issue of Jena Six fatigue, Jozen, do you think that's true?
Yeah.
It's…
Oh, I'm sorry.
I'm mixed up.
Desmond, do you think that's…
